title: The 10 Most Alluring Amusement Parks in the World
text:
The 10 Most Alluring Amusement Parks in the World By Emily Stewart | 08/15/15 - 09:44 AM EDT Reprint 
NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- We may be on the downside of summertime, but you can swing by many of the best amusement parks in the world year-round. 
According to data compiled by Aecom ( ACM - Get Report ) in conjunction with the Entertainment Themed Association, amusement and theme-park turnout is on the upswing. Its 2014 Theme Index indicates that attendance rose 4.1% to 2014 from 2013. Attendance at parks in Asia rose 5%, while amusement-park attendance rose 3% in Europe and 2% in the U.S. 
"Worldwide attendance continues to rise," said Arthur Levine, a theme-park expert who pens a column for About.com . "Companies such as Comcast ( CMCSA - Get Report ) , which was expected to sell off the parks when it acquired NBCUniversal, instead are pouring tons of capital into the parks and reaping huge rewards. The future looks exceptionally bright for the industry." 
Technological innovations are transforming the amusement-park industry and enthralling tourists all over the globe. Rides have become more sophisticated, special effects have intensified, and the theme-park experience has become increasingly participatory and immersive.

"There is greater and greater blending of technologies in theme parks. There is a real push to make things much more intense," said Monty Lunde, CEO of Technifix, an entertainment company that specializes in design, engineering and production. 
Film-themed amusement parks, rides and areas have grown in recent years; they allow attendees to step directly into the fictional world they love brought to life. 
Disney ( DIS - Get Report ) is set to deliver Avatar Land -- which was inspired by the 2009 film of the same name -- to its Animal Kingdom in Florida's Disney World in 2017. "It's like somebody hit print on the movie," said Craig Hanna, who's chief creative officer at Thinkwell Group, a design and production company. 
International expansion has been a major theme in recent years, as well, and the amusement-park industry eagerly awaits the opening of Disney Shanghai in 2016. The park is expected to be spectacular and a one-of-a-kind blended cultural experience. 
"As the industry gets more international, even the bigger players, and especially the bigger players, are learning to be more culturally sensitive than the first time around," said Judith Rubin, a spokeswoman for the Themed Entertainment Association. 
No matter the inspiration, innovation or location, at the core of the amusement-park industry remains one central goal: enjoyment. 
"The market has evolved through several generations into much more of an active, participatory market, but the idea of passive involvement in experiences is still very much appreciated," said Rick Rothschild, a theme-park entertainment consultant and former executive show director at Disney. "How do we actively engage our audience at different levels in different ways to increase their enjoyment or their experience?"
